seg.seg: ... he killed the old warriors.” [63d] Remembering the great king Bimbasāra, [he] pitied his little son, [and] therefore (?) ...

(spoke) to him the Buddha: “(The king) with [his] army will stand by [his] decision and the army will not come against you again.” [64d] Thereupon the Buddha spoke this strophe to the king: If it suits him the man
(The king together) with [his] army will stay with his decision and [his] army will not come again towards you. (cf : ii, 36)
will rob, (but then) others rob the one robbing, the robber becomes the one robbed. [65d] Of each of their own possessions kings are not able to be satiated, [so]
they rob the (lands) [and] villages of others. [But] if their dignity disappears, then others defeat this one. In this way kings become hostile because of [their] insatiability.
If their glory disappears, then others conquer him. (cf : ii, 36)
[66d] The king Prasannaka (let free the Ajātaśatru), set him on [his] throne and gave (him) regality a second time. He summoned [thereupon] Śreṣṭ(h)aka and invited him to a wish: “In your
Er [scil. König Prasannaka] beschied den Śreṣṭhaka zu sich [und] lud ihn zu einem Wunsche ein/stellte ihm einen Wunsch frei [wtl. forderte ihn zu einem Wunsche auf]:
He [i.e. king Prasannaka] summoned Śreṣṭhaka to him [and] invited him to [utter] a wish/granted him a wish.

strength I have met the enemy.” [67d] (This one asked for) regality in Kausala (for seven days). As king he sat, directed in a single direction throughout seven days. In all lands and villages he ordered to do

(good deed[s]), he satiated all beings (by giving them) to eat (and to drink). [68d] He himself invited the Omniscient with [his] community [for] seven days. He ordered the beings to keep the ten good deeds. [For] seven days
Er selbst lud sieben Tage [lang] den Alleswissenden mit der Gemeinde ein.
He himself entertained the Omniscient with [his] community [for] seven days.

he gave clothing in honour of the Omniscient. [To] everyone .... the three garments. [69d] He cherished a wish [and] fell down at the Omniscient’s [feet]: Since I have given to the be(ings) throughout seven days

Er hegte den Wunsch [und] fiel dem Alleswissenden zu Füßen: Weil ich den Wesen sieben Tage hindurch unbekümmert gab und weil ich den Buddha (mit der Gemeinde sieben Tage (lang) einlud), durch diese gute Tat möchte ich die Würde eines Allwissenden erlangen.

He felt the wish [and] fell before the feet of the omniscient: As I have given to the beings unconcernedly [for] seven days, and as I have hosted the Buddha (with the community [for] seven days), by this good deed I want to attain the dignity of an omniscient
and since I (have invited) the Buddha (with [his] community for seven days), by this good deed I wish to obtain the glory of the Omniscient. [70d] A refuge for this blinded world I wish to become.

[And] the Omniscient (made) this prophecy [for] him at this (time): “You (did) [a] great (deed), you achieved [your] thought, you will later become, for all that are of the five kinds of births, shelter [and] refuge.” [71d] In the town of Śrāvastī,
You did a great deed, you achieved your idea.57 You will later be a help and stay for all those of the five birth [forms]. (cf : ii, 37)

in the Jetavana, the Master, (the Buddha, the Omniscient, together) with the crowd [of his community] was. The three Ānantarya [deadly sins] altogether Devadatta committed, [and] he was [re]born in the Avīci-Hell.
Die drei Ānantarya [Todsünden] insgesamt beging Devadatta und wurde in der Avīci-Hölle [wieder-]geboren.
The three Ānantarya [deadly sins] together Devadatta committed, and [he] was [re-]born in the Avīci-hell.
Die drei Todsünden insgesamt beging Devadatta, [und] er wurde in der Avīci-Hölle [wieder]geboren.
The three deadly sins together Devadatta committed, [and] he was [re]born in the Avīci-hell.
[72d] Having just been born, he saw there (many sufferings). (Two guardians of hell(?)) put his body on gravel(?). An iron she-elephant crushed his bones [to] small [bits].
(Zwei Höllenwächter(?)) legten ihm den Körper auf Kies.
(Two guardians of hell(?)) laid his body onto gravel.
A glowing-hot mountain (stood) on his body. [73d] With an iron spike they violently pierced him the crown of his head. Scattered apart [into] small [pieces] was his whole head. It came
Mit einem eisernen Pfahl durchstachen sie ihm heftig den Scheitel: Auseinandergeschleudert wurde ihm [in] klein[en Stücken] der ganze Kopf.
With an iron stake the stabbed the crown of his head violently: in small [bits] his whole head was dashed apart.
at the Buddha’s word (Śāriputra and Maudgalyāyana) (to) see him [and] they questioned him kindly. [74d] To the iron ground the unlucky one fell down, he spoke words to Śāripu-
-tra full of love: (“O Upati)ṣya, I feel terrible suffering. Penetrated into my body have all fires of hell. [75d] And not one syllable
(O Upati)sya, ich erdulde schreckliches Leid.
(Oh Upati)sya, I endure terrible suffering.
the bones small like dust. But yet the Omniscient remembers me with compassion.” To him spoke the son of Śārī
Dennoch erinnert sich meiner der Alleswissende mitleidig.
Still the Omniscient remembers me, full of compassion.

p.note: This leaf, immediately following , includes strophes 63d-76 of the Karmavarga (IX). 4x12 syllable-metre, rhythm = 5/7.
